title: Exporters sound alarm as bank finance remains hard to come by
text:
This represents a huge increase compared with the 2018 survey results, where only 14 per cent of respondents said it was difficult or very difficult to access debt financing.

The struggle is particularly acute for micro-businesses, which employ four or fewer employees.

While 34 per cent of them sought bank loans, only 13 per cent were successful.

In comparison, 45 per cent of large businesses employing more than 200 people sought financing, with a 33 per cent success rate.

The survey's results echo data from the Reserve Bank of Australia, which have shown that bank lending to small businesses has nosedived.

In the June quarter, credit to mining, manufacturing, construction, wholesale and retail trade, and transport and storage went backwards.

Central bank governor Philip Lowe said this month banks were too scared to lend money to small businesses, to the detriment of the economy.

Advertisement

The council's survey found confidence in trading conditions remained relatively high despite an uncertain outlook headlined by the US-China dispute, other trade tensions and the effects of Brexit on global demand.

Offsetting this was the falling exchange rate, giving short-term prospects for exports a lift, and higher commodity prices were also delivering a boost.

These factors produced a mixed picture on business optimism: while 55 per cent of businesses believed their financial outlook would be better over the next two years compared with the past two years, this was down from two-thirds a year earlier.

China worries

Exporters that focus on the US are the most bullish about their prospects, and surprisingly there is some confidence about the UK, as companies look for post-Brexit opportunities.

However, exporters are less optimistic about conditions in China, although one in five companies planning to expand their businesses plan to target Chinese consumers, making it the most popular new market.

Trade Minister Simon Birmingham said the overall survey results were encouraging and vindicated the government's commitment to free trade agreements to improve market access.

“Overall, this report paints a positive outlook for Australian exporters, with almost 80 per cent of those surveyed indicating they were planning to enter at least one new market in the next two years," Senator Birmingham said.

"Expanding opportunities for Australian exporters is a key pillar of our economic plan and builds upon successes that have already fuelled Australia to record levels of exports and a record trade surplus."
description: But despite the tighter credit situation, most businesses continue to be upbeat about overall economic conditions.
